abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rehabilitation Loan
            Project in Lithuania are as follows: overall outcome of the
            project was rated as fully satisfactory, and the performance
            of the Bank and the Borrower were rated as fully
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: 1) the appointment of advisors to the project
            implementation unit (PIU), to provide overall project
            management support and expertise on procurement and
            disbursement, is critical to the success of any operation
            involving new borrowers. In this case, the advisors
            performed an important function of training and knowledge
            transfer to both PIU staff and a broader set of local
            counterparts, which contributed to the sustainable impact of
            the loan. The role of the advisors also evolved and
            eventually decreased over time, resulting in a change in the
            skills mix of the advisors; due to this experience, the
            Borrower was encouraged by the Bank to develop the capacity
            to manage the consultants; 2) active coordination within the
            international community is necessary to deliver the
            technical support to assist the Government to achieve policy
            targets. The structural program outlined in the Memorandum
            of Economic Reform Policies (MERP) provided a useful
            framework to which the international community could anchor
            its support at this early stage when the needs of the
            country were not yet well understood; and 3) the Bank has an
            ambiguous policy on used equipment; developing a clear and
            consistent approach may be useful for future operations.
            Used equipment would be an appropriate solution to meet some
            of the needs of transition economies. However, in the
            proposed used bus procurement to be financed under this
            loan, the Bank's excessive restrictions.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Lithuania is committed
            to economic reform. Its goal is to maintain a stable
            macroeconomic environment while introducing the structural
            reforms necessary to make productive sectors efficient and
            internationally competitive. The objectives of the
            Rehabilitation Loan Project are to support the economic
            reform while at the same time providing critically needed
            foreign exchange finance for essential imports. The loan
            finances the following: (a) imports of inputs essential to
            control further declines in output of the energy and
            agricultural sectors, as well as vitally-needed
            pharmaceutical products; (b) purchases with local currency
            in commercial banks for the import needs of individual
            productive enterprises; and (c) procurement of and
            disbursement operations for the loan, as well as critical
            elements of the reform program, which are being supported
            with technical assistance in a number of areas.
